review_blob: On tap @ McGraths.  Pours a cloudy golden amber, with NO head, nada.  Your standard aroma of orange peel and herbs; coriander.  Clean, yeasty taste one would expect from a wit or weiss... Nothing over the top or groundbreaking here.  Standard.

On tap @ McGraths.  Pours a deep brown, kinda hazy, with a small off-white head.  Sorta sweet, sorta fruity aroma.  Big mouthful of rich, red grapefruit; a touch sour with a sweet finish. Too much citrus here for me, and thats saying something.  Malt does balance somewhat, but the tart grapefruit overpowers all.  OK in small doses.

On tap @ McGraths.  Pours a deep, dark black with a small tan head.  Sweet, malty cherry aroma, like a flat, old fashioned soda.  Sour up front, but not a sour like a good lambic.  Good carbonation bite with a sweet and smooth cherry/malty finish.  Not bad, once you get past the odd sourness.
beer_name: Blue Point Sour Cherry Imperial Stout

review_blob: 2009 bottling.  Pours a relatively clear orange color with a small, off white head.  Earthy, piney aroma; qiute clean with an underlying sweetness.  Decent malt backbone holds up a somewhat fruity, citrusy body.  Herbal finish.  Decent brew.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Wet Hop IPA - Northern Hemisphere

review_blob: Bottle @ Delirium Cafe.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a rocky, tan head.  Dry aroma of roasted malts and coffee.  Interesting body, much different than the NA bottled version; much more substantial, more roasted.  Great dry, mocha finsih.  Waited 8 years for this one, and it was worth it.

2009 bottling.  Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a long lasting, rocky white head.  Very well balanced aroma; lots of bready malts to compliment the bristling hops.  Slightly nutty with hints of vanilla.  Initial dose of malts gives way to a slightly citrusy hoppy finish.  Not bad.

This takes me back 10 years, when we thought Heineken Dark was a crrrazy dark import... silly us.  Pours a clear ruby red color with a small tan head.  Sweet, malty aroma with some caramel.  Again, caramel and malts dominate the body.  Clean, non-abrasive finish.  Not a whole lot going on here except for sweet, crisp, easy drinking beer.  And to think, this was $0.50 cheaper than Heineken green death bottles...

750ml bottle.  Pours a deep brown color with a quickly disappearing tan head.  Boozy aroma, full of citrusy fruits and sweet chocolate, with a roasted nuttiness.  Silky smooth body reveals a very sweet, malty beer.  Hints of chocolate and coffee with a hint of sourness in the sticky sweet finish.  Good, but not outstanding.

Bottle from Wegmans.  Pours a very dark brown color with a giant tan head; very nice.  Malty aroma with some licorice notes.  Coffee, complete with coffee ground bitterness, and toffee are the major players in this medium bodied brew.  Breaking out the classics recently... good!

On tap @ IAH.  Pours a clear amber color with a small offwhite head.  Sweet aroma of bready malts, some caramel.  Medium body reveals more sweetness, honey, with a slightly metallic finish.  Drinkable, standard ale.

Nitro @ BWI.  Pours a clear golden color with a trademark creamy white head.  Somewhat sweet aroma, reminiscent of a shiny new Easton baseball bat and a fresh Band-Aid... Like being in the bottling area @ A-B.  Anyway, very thin, watery body reveals a quite light, sweet butter flavor, more steel, and finally the slightest hint of bitterness.  Notice the diminutive adjectives here... I admit Im a ratings whore and when I saw this on tap, I couldnt resist.  Itll be another few years before I have this again.

Rating #400.  Bottle @ Shadys.  Pours a clear dark amber with no head.  Alcoholic nose, followed by a hint of sweet fruit and spices.  Complex body swirls with brown sugar, molasses, raisins, and tons of malt.  Sticky caramel finish with a punch of alcohol.  Epic in every way.

Pours a hazy orangish-amber with a quickly dissapating white head.  Earthy farmhouse hay combines with a citrusy element in the aroma.  Tart fruitiness, a hint sour with a complement of spices.  Well carbonated body delivers a dry biting finish.  A decent stab at a saison.

On tap @ Bar Louie.  Pours a slightly hazy dark amber color with a small head.  Pungent sweet raisin aroma, lots of brown sugar and sour fruit in the body; random spiciness throughout.  Better than Tremens, but you knew that.

This takes me back to my jr. drinking days... Pours a clear amber color with a quickly disappearing white head.  Aroma of sweet malts, grains, not much else.  Medium malty budy, a bit of sweet caramel and nuttiness.  Not a fan of the style; this would be a sweet gateway beer for some.
On tap @ Bar Louie. Pours a clear dark bronze color with a small white head.  Sweet aroma, light hints of toffee.  Thin body, sweet with an old tea leaf finish. Not a good saison, sorry.

On tap @ Mad Mex Cranberry.  Pours a clear dark amber with an off white head that laces the glass nicely.  Hops are totally overwhelming on the nose, very sharp floral notes.  As expected, hops shine in the body; not a bright citrus hop character, more sappy and thick.  Malts try to hold up, but are just dominated by conical goodness.  Not well rounded, but who cares?

Pours a hazy amber color with a massive off-white head.  Sweet and spicy aroma, lots of banana and cloves.  Relatively light bodied and easy drinking, malty brew finishes with a menthol dryness.  Nutmeg and cinnamon shine through here... great, easy drinking autumn beer.
On tap @ RR.  Pours a clear blonde color with a small white head.  Very tart, sour aroma, a bit of funky barnyard.  Very sour body, some woodsy flavors.  Tart, sour finish.  Stellar beer.

On tap @ RR.  Pours a clear copper color with a small head.  Nice sweet aroma, accompanied by a grassy hop character.  Tangy hop bitterness shines through the sweet backbone, Id say middle of the road as RR IPAs go.
On tap @ RR.  Pours a clear gold color with no head.  Lemony, yeasty aroma, lots of funky brett in the light  body.  Tasty!

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a ever-so-slightly clody orange with a decent sized white head.  Big citrus-hop aroma, lots of orange on this one.  Suprisingly light bodied, in a good, drinkable way.  Bright frutiness dominates the mouth; lots of grapefruit, hint of watermellon, pear.  Great bitter hop finish.  Welcome to west coast IPAs...
On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a clear orange color with a small white head.  Light citrus hop on the aroma, big grapefruit hop body.  Quite light and refreshing.  Maybe a session IPA... ?
On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a deep copper color with a lacing head.  Sweet aroma that gives way to a leafy hoppiness.  Medium body, a bit sweet and grainy, with a sticky bitter-hop finish. Not bad.

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a deep black with a small tan head.  Big coffee aroma, lots of roastiness here.  Very sweet and malty, roasted coffee really shines through.  Finishes like, well, a cold cup o joe; bitter, but satisfying.  Try it!

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a deep black color with a small off-white  head.  Smoky, earthy aroma, roasted malts.  Again, lots of roasted malt in the body, licorice, with a sweet tanginess.  I like the style, love this beer.

Pours a cloudy amber color with a small off white head.  Yeast dominates the aroma, very well spiced.  Quite sweet with hints of anise, allspice, and a large yeast presence.  Warming finish for a 7.5 abv beer.  Grab it while you can.

On tap @ La Trappe.  Pours a slightly cloudy golden hue with a nice white head.  Mellow apple aroma with a hint of hay.  Sweetness is quickly subdued by a sour finish.  Average for the style... Not recommended if youre looking for a nice Geuze.

On tap @ brewpub.  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head; good lacing.  Citrusy, hoppy aroma, very bright.  Smooth body, easy drinking with a hint of sweetness balancing the bitter hop finish.  Average.
On tap @ brewpub.  Pours a deep black color with a foamy tan head.  A slight sweetness lurks behind the otherwise hoppy &#

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a black color with a lasting tan head.  Caramel aroma, very sharp w a hop note; some dark fruits.  Chocolate taste quickly gives way to dark cherries, deeply complex bittersweetness.  Sweet finish, worth a try.
On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a clear copper color with a small white head.  Quite a hoppy, herbal aroma.  Tasty, hoppy body; very herbal with hints of pine and malt.  Bitter, but refreshing.  Tasty!

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a slightly hazy orange, small head.  Very hoppy and citrusy nose, gives way to a grapefruit, sweet orange, and bitter explosion.  Could be a bit more balanced, but why? Tasty!

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a very deep brown with a lacing tan head.  Tons of roasted nuts and sweet malt in the aroma.  Nuttiness carries over to the body, with a strong malt backing; finishes with a actue bitter bite.  A new twist on the venerable brown ale, and I approve!

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a very dark brown with a small off-white head.  Sharp, hoppy nose with a touch of sweetness.  With the body of a much larger beer, the nutty, malty character is matched to a biting hop finish.  Id have to put this in an "old ale" style, certainly not an AIPA.
Pours a clear amber color with a small white head.  Grassy aroma, biting bitterness.  Easy drinking, could be a good session brew.
beer_name: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale

review_blob: Bottle from Wegmans.  Pours an ever-so-slightly hazy copper color with a stable, white head.  Aroma of cloves, sweet malt, and alcohol; spicy.    Medium bodied but silky smooth, super malty and sweet.  Spices shine here; stars are anise and cloves.  Candied orange finish.  Very rich, very far from a traditional wit.  Kudos to BBC for trying something different.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial White

review_blob: Bottle from Wegmans.  Pours an oily black with a small, lacing brown head.  Sweet chocolate bar with a trace of alcohol in the aroma.  Viscous body, lots of coffee, roasted malts, and maple syrup, very sweet.  Again, sweet, but burning finish.  Tasty, well done brew.  Hard to believe its a Boston Beer product!
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: Bottle from Wegmans.  Pours a very deep reddish brown with a large, rocky, tan head.  Caramel nose, sweet and slightly roasted.  Big anise/vanilla profile; thin mouthfeel makes this one an easy drinker.  Malty body is offset by a well hopped finish.  Another winner from Victory.

beer_brewer_name: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
review_blob: Bottle @ Shadys.  Pours a beautiful amber color with no head to speak of.  Lots of sweet malt on the nose, spicy with caramel.  Sticky sweet body, caramel interlude, finishing with a biting hop bitterness.  Epic.

beer_brewer_name: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
review_blob: Bottle @ Shadys.  Pours a thick black color with no head to mention.  Very sweet aroma littered with plums, raisins, even some maple.  Not much carbonation here, but a healthy dose of chocolate, toffee, caramel, and malt (of course)!  Huge, epic, and super sweet; finish lingers for quite a while.

Bottle @ Shadys.  Pours a clear amber color with a small white head.  Aroma is rather earthy and hoppy.  Easy drinking.  Quite malty, but theres still a nice grapefruit taste here.  Tasty and quaffable.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle @ Shadys.  Pours black, oily, and flat; no head.  Lots of booze on the nose, otherwise, a ton of malt, cocoa powder, and raisins.  Slick mouthfeel gives way to a giant blast of malt, followed by chocolate, by the truckload.  Sweet finish; Im a lover of the style, but this may be too sweet, needs more balance.

Bottle from Publick House.  Pours a slightly hazed golden color with a nice white head.  Trademark Belgian saison in light form.  Fresh risen dough and yeast dominate the nose, with the slightest hint of hay/cloves.  Nicely carbonated; I get lots of lemon zest, return of the hay and cloves, with a hint of sour in the bitter finish.  Very bright beer, quite refreshing.  Excellent beer, and at 3.5%, you can enjoy this one all day, if you can find it...

Bottle from Publick House.  Pours a deep reddish brown with a lasting off-white head.  Awesome aroma of dark chocolate, cherries, and some nuttiness, maybe dates.  Very malty up front, next comes sour cherries, finishing with a hint of bitersweet nuts.  Nicely carbonated, great mouthfeel.  Odd mixture of flavors, well done!

Bottle from Publick House.  Pours a very dark brown color with a small tan head.  Extremely sweet aroma, chocolate with a touch of roasted coffee.  Medium body; not too heavy, but not light, either.  More licorice than chocolate or caramel, but all are detectable.  Very sour finish with limited carbonation, not what I was expecting.  Different.

Bottle from Publick House.  Pours a murky, funky brown with a lacing off-white head.  Earthy aroma, lots of sweet, chocolaty malts, with a hint of light fruit and cloves.  Dark chocolate dominates, a little bittersweet.  Quite malty, but not overwhelming.  Great biting, bitter finish.  A favorite style from a favorite brewer = a certain "4".

Bottle from Publick House.  Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head.  Light, sweet, and lemony aroma.  Body bubbles away with carbonation.  Its an easy drinking beer, light mouthfeel, citrus taste dances with the yeastiness well.  Love the peppery finish; a hint of smokiness, too.

Bottle from Wells.  Pours a slightly hazy orangish yellow color with a large, rocky head.  Big herbal aroma, grassy, very earthy.   Some citrus in the flavor, biting hop finish is paired well with malty body.  A good IIPA.
beer_name: Laughing Dog Alpha Dog Imperial IPA

review_blob: Bottle from Wells.  Pours a deep reddish-brown with a small white head.  Aroma of raisins, caramel, and malt; a little faint.  Big, creamy body, lots of sweet malt, but with a hint of sourness.  Dry finish.  Average.
